title: Series system with exponentially distributed component lifetimes
text: principle object study series system consisting \(m\) components. interested estimating component lifetimes masked data. masking comes two independent forms: Censored system failure times, e.g., right-censoring. Masked component cause failure, comes form candidate sets, candidate sets satisfy following set conditions: \(C_1\): index failed component candidate set, .e., \(\Pr\{K_i \\mathcal{C}_i\} = 1\). \(C_2\): probability \(C_i\) given \(K_i\) \(T_i\) equally probable failed component varies components candidate set, .e., \(\Pr\{\mathcal{C}_i=c_i|K_i=j,T_i=t_i\} = \Pr\{C_i=c_i|K_i=j',T_i=t_i\}\) \(j,j' \c_i\). \(C_3\): masking probabilities independent \(\boldsymbol{\theta}\), .e., \(\Pr\{\mathcal{C}_i=c_i|K_i=j,T_i=t_i\}\) function \(\boldsymbol{\theta}\). means, whatever generative mechanism underlying \(\mathcal{C}_1,\ldots,\mathcal{C}_n\), explicit knowledge \(\boldsymbol{\theta}\), \(\) candidate set \(\mathcal{C}_i\) may depend realizations \(T_{1},\ldots,T_{n}\) factors explicitly statistical model described.

what: Bernoulli candidate model that satisfies \(C_1\), \(C_2\), and \(C_3\)
title: Series system with exponentially distributed component lifetimes
text: long satisfy conditions \(C_1\), \(C_2\), \(C_3\), reduced likelihood function assumes conditions obtains MLEs full likelihood function. follows, describe Bernoulli candidate set model generates candidate sets satisfy conditions. Bernoulli candidate model function component cause failure k parameters m p, component cause failure indexed j, j candidate set otherwise component indexed j candidate set probability specified p, may either procedure sampling distribution codomain [0,1] constant function. masked data, column k failed component index. integer, number components candidate set. function procedure p : integer -> [0,1], defaults function(n) runif(n). source code md_bernoulli_candidate_C1_C2_C3:
code: md_bernoulli_candidate_C1_C2_C3(md, m, p = function(n) runif(n)) md_bernoulli_candidate_C1_C2_C3 <- function(md,m,p=function(n) runif(n)) {     stopifnot(!is.null(md$k))     n <- nrow(md)     stopifnot(n > 0)      x <- matrix(NA,nrow=n,ncol=m)     u <- matrix(runif(m*n),nrow=n)     gam <- p(n)      for (i in 1:n)     {         for (j in 1:m)         {             x[i,j] <- ifelse(md$k[i]==j,                              T,                              u[i,j] < gam[i])         }     }      x <- tibble::as_tibble(x)     colnames(x) <- paste0("x",1:m)     md %>% dplyr::bind_cols(x) }

title: Series system with exponentially distributed component lifetimes
text: straightforward series system estimate series system exponentially distributed component lifetimes. Suppose exponential series system \(m\) components parameterized following R code: \(\boldsymbol{\theta }= (1, 1.25, 1.75)'\). , component assigned index \(j\) exponentially distributed lifetime failure rate \(\theta_j\), e.g., \(\theta_2 = 1.25\) failure rate component indexed \(2\). Let’s simulate generating lifetimes \(n=300\) series systems: , used function md_series_lifetime, decorate masked data md consisting \(m=3\) component lifetimes masked data also includes series system failure time (column \(t\)) comoponent cause failure (column \(k\)). get help , type ?md_series_lifetime.

title: Series system with exponentially distributed component lifetimes
text: simulate right-censoring, right-censoring time chosen probability \(\Pr\{T_i > \tau\} = 0.75\), :
code: q <- 0.25 tau <- rep(-(1/sum(theta))*log(q),n) md <- md %>% md_series_lifetime_right_censoring(tau)

code: nparams <- c(2,2,1) hs <- list() Rs <- list() hs[[1]] <- function(t,theta) theta[2]/theta[1]*(t/theta[1])^(theta[2]-1) Rs[[1]] <- function(t,theta) exp((-t/theta[1])^theta[2])  hs[[2]] <- function(t,theta) theta[2]/theta[1]*(t/theta[1])^(theta[2]-1) Rs[[2]] <- function(t,theta) exp((-t/theta[1])^theta[2])  hs[[3]] <- function(t,rate) rate Rs[[3]] <- function(t,rate) exp(-t*rate)  print(hs[[1]](2,theta[1:2])) #> [1] 0.00039 print(hs[[2]](2,theta[3:4])) #> [1] 9.85e-05 print(hs[[3]](2,theta[5])) #> [1] 0.347  print(Rs[[1]](2,theta[1:2])) #> [1] NaN print(Rs[[2]](2,theta[3:4])) #> [1] NaN print(Rs[[3]](2,theta[5])) #> [1] 0.5  knitr::knit_exit()

what:
Masked data approximately satisfies the following set of conditions:
C1: Pr(K[i] in C[i]) = 1
